ratings.comment: He has really interesting lectures with bits of stories and experiences mixed in with all the chemistry and microbiology. He is obviously very passionate about fermented foods and the craft cheese and beer industry. This class was my favorite I've taken so far.
One of my favorite professors.  Going to lecture is essential for doing well. But if you take the time to study, tests are just on material covered in lecture. Very clear and interesting.

Attend lecture every day, its the best way to succeed. Study each slide and know just about everything on it. Steele loves questions where he asks you to list 4 out of 6 qualities. Lab is always straight forward but the reports can be tedious.
Terrible class. Tests are multiple choice and basically require you to regurgitate details from lecture slides. Do not take this class. I wish I could have taken a food science lab instead.

I decided to switch my major to Food Sci after taking this course. Dr. Steele is a great lecturer, and is very approachable. Exams were fair, lectures were interesting, and the material can be applied to everyday life. The lab reports were confusing and tedious at times. Ask questions. Also, exam/lab report grading is slow. Be prepared to wait.

This was one of my favorite classes I've taken. It wasn't easy, the tests were long and challenging, but do-able. Lab reports were a pain, but if you follow directions and ask questions you'll be fine. He was great lecturer and taught things in a way that made them seem relevant to the real word and easy to understand.
Good thing that Beth Briczinski is the lecturer he team teaches with, because otherwise Food Sci 301 would be even more unbearable at times.
